name: Scandium
Analysis: The atomic radius decreases from scandium to nickel due to the poor shielding effect of d-orbitals and increasing effective nuclear charge. The d-orbitals have low shielding ability, causing the outer electrons to be more strongly attracted to the nucleus, resulting in a gradual decrease in atomic radius. However, from nickel to zinc, the atomic radius increases due to electron-electron repulsion in the 3d subshell. As more electrons occupy the 3d orbitals, inter-electron repulsion counteracts the nuclear attraction, leading to a slight expansion in atomic size. This effect is more pronounced in zinc, making its atomic radius larger than that of copper.

name: Titanium
Analysis: The atomic radius decreases from scandium to titanium due to poor shielding effect of d-orbitals and addition of electron in same 3d subshell leading to increased effective nuclear charge. The shielding power of d-orbital is low and thus the outer electrons will be attracted more towards the nucleus resulting in a decrease in atomic radius.

name: Vanadium
Analysis: The atomic radius decreases from titanium to vanadium due to poor shielding effect of d-orbitals and addition of electron in same 3d subshell leading to increased effective nuclear charge. The shielding power of d-orbital is low and thus the outer electrons will be attracted more towards the nucleus resulting in a decrease in atomic radius.

name: Chromium
Analysis: The atomic radius decreases from vanadium to chromium due to poor shielding effect of d-orbitals and addition of electron in same 3d subshell leading to increased effective nuclear charge. The shielding power of d-orbital is low and thus the outer electrons will be attracted more towards the nucleus resulting in a decrease in atomic radius.

name: Manganese
Analysis: The atomic radius decreases from chromium to manganese due to poor shielding effect of d-orbitals and addition of electron in same 3d subshell leading to increased effective nuclear charge. The shielding power of d-orbital is low and thus the outer electrons will be attracted more towards the nucleus resulting in a decrease in atomic radius.

name: Iron
Analysis: There is only slight decrease in atomic radius of iron. As the number of electrons in the 3d subshell increases to 6 there are 2 electrons in same d-orbital and thus, there will be inter-electron repulsion, which may cause an increase in atomic radius. However, simultaneously the atomic radius decreases due to increased effective nuclear charge. The combination of both effects leads to neither increase nor decrease in the atomic radius to a significant extent.

name: Cobalt
Analysis: There is only slight decrease in atomic radius of cobalt. As the number of electrons in the 3d subshell increases to 7 there are 2 electrons in 2 similar d-orbitals and thus, there will be inter-electron repulsion, which may cause an increase in atomic radius. However, simultaneously the atomic radius decreases due to increased effective nuclear charge. The combination of both effects leads to neither increase nor decrease in the atomic radius to a significant extent.

name: Nickel
Analysis: There is only slight decrease in atomic radius of nickel. As the number of electrons in the 3d subshell increases to 8 there are 2 electrons in 3 similar d-orbitals and thus, there will be inter-electron repulsion, which may cause an increase in atomic radius. However, simultaneously the atomic radius decreases due to increased effective nuclear charge. The combination of both effects leads to neither increase nor decrease in the atomic radius to a significant extent.

name: Copper
Analysis: The atomic radius of copper is greater than that of nickel. As the number of electrons in the 3d subshell increases, there will be inter-electron repulsion, which may cause an increase in atomic radius. However, simultaneously the atomic radius decreases due to increased effective nuclear charge. There will be a domination of electron-electron repulsion, leading to an increase in copper's atomic radius.

name: Zinc
Analysis: The atomic radius of zinc is greater than that of copper. As the number of electrons in the 3d subshell increases, there will be inter-electron repulsion, which may cause an increase in atomic radius. However, simultaneously the atomic radius decreases due to increased effective nuclear charge. There will be a domination of electron-electron repulsion, leading to an increase in zinc atomic radius.

name: Yttrium
Analysis: The atomic radius decreases from yttrium to rhodium due to the poor shielding effect of d-orbitals increasing nuclear charge, while the number of shells remains constant. From technetium to rhodium, electron-electron repulsion in the 4d subshell counterbalances nuclear attraction, resulting in minimal change in atomic size. The radius then increases from rhodium to cadmium as electron-electron repulsion in d-orbitals dominates.

name: Zirconium
Analysis: The atomic radius decreases from yttrium to zirconium due to an increase in effective nuclear charge, with the increase in protons and electrons but the number of shells remaining the same.

name: Niobium
Analysis: The atomic radius decreases from zirconium to niobium due to an increase in effective nuclear charge, with the increase in protons and electrons but the number of shells remaining the same.

name: Molybdenum
Analysis: The atomic radius decreases from niobium to molybdenum due to an increase in effective nuclear charge, with the increase in protons and electrons but the number of shells remaining the same.

name: Technetium
Analysis: The atomic radius decreases from molybdenum to technetium due to an increase in effective nuclear charge, with the increase in protons and electrons but the number of shells remaining the same.

name: Ruthenium
Analysis: The atomic radius from technetium to ruthenium is almost similar as the number of electrons in the 4d subshell increases and exceeds 5. Thus there will be electron-electron repulsion that will try to increase the atomic radius, but the increase in the effective nuclear charge tries to decrease the atomic radius. On combining both effects, the atomic radius will neither decrease nor increase to a significant extent.

name: Rhodium
Analysis: The atomic radius from ruthenium to rhodium is almost similar as the number of electrons in the 4d subshell increases and exceeds 5. Thus there will be electron-electron repulsion that will try to increase the atomic radius, but the increase in the effective nuclear charge tries to decrease the atomic radius. On combining both effects, the atomic radius will neither decrease nor increase to a significant extent.

name: Palladium
Analysis: The atomic radius increases from rhodium to palladium due to an increase in electron-electron repulsion in the d-orbitals as the dominating factor.

name: Silver
Analysis: The atomic radius increases from palladium to silver due to an increase in electron-electron repulsion in the d-orbitals as the dominating factor.

name: Cadmium
Analysis: The atomic radius increases from silver to cadmium due to an increase in electron-electron repulsion in the d-orbitals as the dominating factor.

name: Hafnium
Analysis: The atomic radius increases from cadmium to hafnium due to dominant electron-electron repulsion in d-orbitals. It then decreases from hafnium to osmium as poor shielding by d- and f-orbitals enhances nuclear attraction. From osmium to mercury, the atomic radius increases due to rising electron-electron repulsion as d-orbital occupancy exceeds five.

name: Tantalum
Analysis: The atomic radius decreases from hafnium to tantalum due to an increase in effective nuclear charge and poor shielding effect of electrons in orbitals of 4f and 5d subshells. The poor shielding effects leads to greater attraction of outershell electrons towards the nucleus causing decrease in the atomic radius.

name: Tungsten
Analysis: The atomic radius decreases from tantalum to tungsten due to an increase in effective nuclear charge and poor shielding effect of electrons in orbitals of 4f and 5d subshells. The poor shielding effects leads to higher attraction of outershell electrons towards the nucleus causing decrease in the atomic radius.

name: Rhenium
Analysis: The atomic radius decreases from tungsten to rhenium due to an increase in effective nuclear charge and poor shielding effect of electrons in orbitals of 4f and 5d subshells. The poor shielding effects leads to more attraction of outershell electrons towards the nucleus causing decrease in the atomic radius.

name: Osmium
Analysis: The atomic radius decreases from rhenium to osmium due to an increase in effective nuclear charge as the number of shells and poor shielding effect of electrons in orbitals of 4f and 5d subshells. The poor shielding effects leads to more attraction of outershell electrons towards the nucleus causing decrease in the atomic radius. There is only slight decrease in the atomic radius due to the number of electrons in d-orbitals exceeds 5 and thus inter electronic repulsion occurs.

name: Iridium
Analysis: The atomic radius slightly increases from osmium to iridium due to increase in the number of electrons in d-orbitals that leads to electron-electron repulsion.

name: Platinum
Analysis: The atomic radius increases from iridium to platinum due to increase in the number of electrons in d-orbitals that leads to electron-electron repulsion.

name: Gold
Analysis: The atomic radius increases from platinum to gold due to increase in the number of electrons in d-orbitals that leads to electron-electron repulsion.

name: Mercury
Analysis: The atomic radius increases from gold to mercury due to increase in the number of electrons in d-orbitals that leads to electron-electron repulsion.

name: Rutherfordium
Analysis: The atomic radius is not available for the fourth transition elements with atomic number ranging from 104 to 112. However, as a general trend, the atomic radius should decrease on moving across the period from rutherfordium to copernicium due to increased effective nuclear charge and the poor shielding effect.

name: Dubnium
Analysis: The atomic radius is not available for the transition elements with atomic number ranging from 104 to 112. However, as a general trend, the atomic radius should decrease on moving across the period due to increased effective nuclear charge and the poor shielding effect of electrons in 5f and 6d subshells causing actinide contraction.
